Description: This consent order concerns violations by American Airlines, Inc. (American Airlines) of 14 CFR 259.4 (the Department's tarmac delay rule), 49 U.S.C. 41712 (prohibition against unfair and deceptive practices), and 49 U.S.C. 42301 (requirement to adhere to a carrier's tarmac delay contingency plan).

Description: The Department of Justice announced a settlement with American Airlines Inc. resolving the government's concerns regarding American's alleged violations of a 1994 consent decree. American agreed to pay a $3 million civil penalty, which included reimbursement to the government for its investigation.

Secondary Offense: Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act
Description: The Department of Justice reached an agreement with American Airlines to resolve a class action lawsuit alleging that the company violated the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994 . The Department's complaint, filed in 2006, alleged that American did not allow three named plaintiff pilots, and a class of similarly situated pilots, to accrue vacation and sick leave benefits while on military leave to the same extent as pilots on comparable forms of non-military leave.

This consent order concerns violations of 14 CFR Part 259 and 49 U.S.C. ? 41712 involving the failure by American Eagle Airlines, Inc. to adhere to the assurances in its contingency plan for lengthy tarmac delays that the carrier would not permit a domestic flight to remain on the tarmac for more than three hours without providing passengers an opportunity to deplane.
